Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violation identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (248) 975-5053.

ALLEGATION #1:
Staff administered medication to the wrong resident.
INVESTIGATION:
On 1/19/20, Administrator S said she left a voice mail for the referral source notifying
her that Resident M was given another resident’s medication in error. The message
indicated that medical personnel were consulted and Resident M was not experiencing
2

adverse effects of taking the wrong medication. An online complaint was filed with
DCWL on 1/21/20.
I interviewed Staff 1 on 1/27/20. She has worked at the facility for six weeks and has
no previous experience working in child caring institutions. Staff 1 works the midnight
shift and was trained in medication dispensing last month.
I asked Staff 1 to run through her process of dispensing medication in detail. She said
she logs into the medication website and begins with the first child that shows up on the
screen. She clicks the child’s picture, pulls the medication out of the drawer and scans
it as she puts each pill into a cup. She pours water. Depending where the child is
located, she said she either calls him to her or takes the medication to the child.
On Sunday 1/19/20 at 8am, Staff 1 recalled her coworker was cooking breakfast for the
boys when she came out of the medication room with a cup of Resident K’s pills.
Resident M was the next child to receive pills “so he was in my mind.” The residents
were cleaning their rooms. Three of them exited their asking for brooms and other
supplies. “We couldn’t meet all of their needs at once. I told all the kids to hold on and
let me finish. I called Resident M and gave him the meds. Then it clicked in my head
(those were Resident K’s pills).”
Staff 1 said she dispensed 3 pills to Resident M in error at 8am. According to the MAR,
she gave Depakote 250mg., Intuniv 2 mg. and Risperdal 1 mg. Resident M is actually
prescribed Tenex (similar to Intuniv) 1 mg. and Seroquel 25mg. Staff 1 said she
immediately notified her supervisor of the error and wrote an incident report as directed.
Administrator 1 said Supervisor 1 contacted her, Administrator 1 contacted the facility’s
nurse and the nurse texted the facility’s psychiatrist. Instructions from medical
personnel were passed back down the chain to Staff 1 to flush the child’s system with
water, assure he takes meals and monitor him for adverse side effects. Staff 1 was
instructed to also give Resident M his prescribed dose of Seroquel but to hold the
Tenex.
3

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written health
service policies and procedures addressing all of the
following:
(e) Dispensing medication.
ANALYSIS: Staff 1 dispensed the wrong medication to Resident M. Staff
1 noticed her error and immediately sought direction from
supervision who contacted medical personnel. Instructions
were given and followed. Resident M experienced no known
adverse effects from taking the wrong medication.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION #2:
Residents A and M AWOLed from the facility without coats and shoes implying
inadequate staff supervision.
INVESTIGATION:
Supervisor 1 was interviewed collaboratively with Government Worker 1. He has
worked as the midnight shift supervisor for over 10 years. Supervisor 1 said he was
covering Stoner Cottage for a direct care worker who had gone home ill in the early
hours of Saturday. Resident M woke up at 2am and would not go back to sleep.
Resident S woke at 5-5:30am. “I tried to keep them quiet in their rooms.” Soon, all of
the residents were awake. “The cottage was in an uproar.” Three of them were running
around the cottage, chasing each other and playing.
Before daybreak, Residents A, M and S exited the cottage wearing only pajamas. They
left without shoes or coats. The weather was rainy with a temperature in the mid-30’s.
“They stayed out in front of the cottage. I visually kept an eye on them.” When the
dayshift staff arrived, Supervisor 1 went outdoors and followed the residents on the
premises. “I caught up with them in the parking lot.” Supervisor 1 managed to convince
Resident S to return to the cottage on his own. The other two boys walked toward the
woods. “I could no longer see them, but I could hear them. I followed their tracks to an
opening in the wire fence. I walked (in the community) yelling for Residents A and M for
30 minutes.” Then Supervisor 1 said he returned to the campus and directed a staff to
go to the police station to file a missing person’s report. “The kids were at the police
station when she arrived and she brought them back.”
4

Resident A, age 6, was interviewed by Government Worker 1. He told her he and two
peers decided to AWOL and that no staff followed them. Resident A said the boys got
candy at the police station.
Resident M, age 8, was interviewed collaboratively with Government Worker 1. He
said Supervisor 1 was working when he and other residents were running around the
cottage. Three boys left the cottage. It was cold outside. “Resident A took his shoes
off outside and Resident S had no shoes. Resident S wanted to go back (to the
cottage). He didn’t go off-grounds. Supervisor 1 came looking for us, but we got away.
A guy picked us up and took us to the police station.”
Resident S, age 7, was interviewed collaboratively with Government Worker 1. He
has cognitive limitations and a speech impediment. Resident S said he and Residents
A and M went down the street and Supervisor 1 followed them. “Residents A and M
walked in the water.” Resident S had no coat or shoes on. Supervisor 1 asked him to
return to the cottage and he did.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care, and
other staff on duty to perform the prescribed functions
required by these administrative rules and in the agency's
program statement and to provide for the continual needs,
protection, and supervision of residents.
ANALYSIS: The evidence shows Supervisor 1 was monitoring the residents
appropriately before they AWOLed from the cottage in the dark
without shoes and coats. Supervisor 1 followed the residents on
foot, across and off the campus into the community. He
searched for them for 30 minutes. A staff person was sent to
file missing person’s reports and found the residents at the
Redford police station.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION:
Once an acceptable corrective action plan is submitted, I recommend this facility
continue its current licensing status.
